    70→    58→    38→    15→     3→## Issue Details
    71→    59→    39→    16→     4→- **ID:** PAN-4
    72→    60→    40→    17→     5→- **Title:** Set up Traefik + panopticon.dev local domain
    73→    61→    41→    18→     6→- **URL:** https://github.com/eltmon/panopticon-cli/issues/4
    74→    62→    42→    19→     7→
    75→    63→    43→    20→     8→## Description
    76→    64→    44→    21→     9→## Overview
    77→    65→    45→    22→    10→Configure Panopticon to be accessible at `https://panopticon.dev` locally using Traefik reverse proxy and mkcert for SSL certificates.
    78→    66→    46→    23→    11→
    79→    67→    47→    24→    12→## Goals
    80→    68→    48→    25→    13→- Local HTTPS access via `https://panopticon.dev`
    81→    69→    49→    26→    14→- Automatic SSL certificate generation with mkcert
    82→    70→    50→    27→    15→- Traefik as reverse proxy for routing
    83→    71→    51→    28→    16→- Works across Linux, macOS, Windows/WSL2
    84→    72→    52→    29→    17→
    85→    73→    53→    30→    18→## Technical Requirements
    86→    74→    54→    31→    19→
    87→    75→    55→    32→    20→### 1. Traefik Configuration
    88→    76→    56→    33→    21→- Docker-based Traefik setup
    89→    77→    57→    34→    22→- Dynamic configuration for Panopticon services
    90→    78→    58→    35→    23→- Dashboard accessible (optional, for debugging)
    91→    79→    59→    36→    24→
    92→    80→    60→    37→    25→### 2. SSL Certificates
    93→    81→    61→    38→    26→- Use mkcert for local CA and certificates
    94→    82→    62→    39→    27→- Auto-trust in system certificate store
    95→    83→    63→    40→    28→- Wildcard cert for `*.panopticon.dev` if needed
    96→    84→    64→    41→    29→
    97→    85→    65→    42→    30→### 3. DNS Resolution
    98→    86→    66→    43→    31→- `/etc/hosts` entry for Linux/macOS
    99→    87→    67→    44→    32→- Windows hosts file for WSL2
   100→    88→    68→    45→    33→- Document dnsmasq alternative for wildcard domains
   101→    89→    69→    46→    34→
   102→    90→    70→    47→    35→### 4. Service Routing
   103→    91→    71→    48→    36→| URL | Service |
   104→    92→    72→    49→    37→|-----|---------|
   105→    93→    73→    50→    38→| `https://panopticon.dev` | Frontend (port 3001) |
   106→    94→    74→    51→    39→| `https://panopticon.dev/api` | API server (port 3002) |
   107→    95→    75→    52→    40→
   108→    96→    76→    53→    41→## Acceptance Criteria
   109→    97→    77→    54→    42→- [ ] `https://panopticon.dev` loads the dashboard
   110→    98→    78→    55→    43→- [ ] API calls work via `/api` path

   557→   545→     1→# PAN-4: Traefik + Local Domain Setup - STATE
   558→   546→     2→
   559→   547→     3→## Issue Summary
   560→   548→     4→Set up Traefik reverse proxy with HTTPS for local Panopticon development.
   561→   549→     5→
   562→   550→     6→## Domain Decision
   563→   551→     7→
   564→   552→     8→**Issue title says "panopticon.dev" but PRD specifies "pan.localhost"**
   565→   553→     9→
   566→   554→    10→The PRD (which is the authoritative source) uses `*.localhost` domains:
   567→   555→    11→- `pan.localhost` - Panopticon dashboard
   568→   556→    12→- `traefik.pan.localhost` - Traefik dashboard
   569→   557→    13→- `feature-{issue}.{project}.localhost` - Workspace frontends
   570→   558→    14→- `api-feature-{issue}.{project}.localhost` - Workspace APIs
   571→   559→    15→
   572→   560→    16→**Decision:** Follow the PRD and use `pan.localhost` (not `panopticon.dev`).
   573→   561→    17→
   574→   562→    18→**Rationale:**
   575→   563→    19→- `.localhost` is a reserved TLD that resolves to 127.0.0.1 on most systems
   576→   564→    20→- No risk of collision with real domains
   577→   565→    21→- Better cross-platform support
   578→   566→    22→- Consistent with workspace URL patterns already in MYN
   579→   567→    23→
   580→   568→    24→## Architecture Decisions (from PRD)
   581→   569→    25→
   582→   570→    26→### 1. Traefik Runs in Docker Only
   583→   571→    27→- **Not** containerizing the dashboard itself
   584→   572→    28→- Traefik proxies to host-based services via `host.docker.internal`
   585→   573→    29→- Dashboard continues to run on ports 3001 (frontend) and 3002 (API)
   586→   574→    30→
   587→   575→    31→### 2. Directory Structure
   588→   576→    32→```
   589→   577→    33→~/.panopticon/
   590→   578→    34→├── traefik/
   591→   579→    35→│   ├── docker-compose.yml      # Traefik container definition
   592→   580→    36→│   ├── traefik.yml             # Static config
   593→   581→    37→│   ├── dynamic/                # Dynamic configs (per-workspace)
   594→   582→    38→│   │   └── panopticon.yml      # Dashboard routing config
   595→   583→    39→│   └── certs/
   596→   584→    40→│       ├── _wildcard.pan.localhost.pem
   597→   585→    41→│       └── _wildcard.pan.localhost-key.pem
   598→   586→    42→├── certs/                      # mkcert certificates (existing)
   599→   587→    43→└── config.toml                 # Updated with traefik settings
   600→   588→    44→```
   601→   589→    45→
   602→   590→    46→### 3. mkcert Certificate Generation
   603→   591→    47→```bash
   604→   592→    48→mkcert "*.pan.localhost" "*.localhost" localhost 127.0.0.1 ::1
   605→   593→    49→```
   606→   594→    50→Generates wildcard certs for:
   607→   595→    51→- `*.pan.localhost` (Panopticon dashboard, Traefik dashboard)
   608→   596→    52→- `*.localhost` (project workspaces like `*.myn.localhost`)
   609→   597→    53→
   610→   598→    54→### 4. URL Routing
   611→   599→    55→| URL | Proxies To |
   612→   600→    56→|-----|------------|
   613→   601→    57→| `https://pan.localhost` | `http://host.docker.internal:3001` (dashboard frontend) |
   614→   602→    58→| `https://pan.localhost/api/*` | `http://host.docker.internal:3002` (dashboard API) |
   615→   603→    59→| `https://traefik.pan.localhost:8080` | Traefik dashboard |
   616→   604→    60→
   617→   605→    61→### 5. DNS Resolution
   618→   606→    62→
   619→   607→    63→#### Linux/macOS
   620→   608→    64→Add to `/etc/hosts`:
   621→   609→    65→```
   622→   610→    66→127.0.0.1 pan.localhost traefik.pan.localhost
   623→   611→    67→```
   624→   612→    68→Note: Only static entries needed. Wildcard `*.localhost` resolves automatically on modern systems.
   625→   613→    69→
   626→   614→    70→#### WSL2/Windows
   627→   615→    71→dnsmasq for wildcard DNS + Windows hosts sync:
   628→   616→    72→```bash
   629→   617→    73→# In /etc/dnsmasq.d/panopticon.conf
   630→   618→    74→address=/localhost/127.0.0.1
   631→   619→    75→```
   632→   620→    76→
   633→   621→    77→### 6. CLI Integration
   634→   622→    78→
   635→   623→    79→New commands:
   636→   624→    80→- `pan install` - Enhanced to set up Traefik (already has mkcert setup)
   637→   625→    81→- `pan up` - Start Traefik along with dashboard
   638→   626→    82→- `pan down` - Stop Traefik along with dashboard
   639→   627→    83→
   640→   628→    84→Config additions to `~/.panopticon/config.toml`:
   641→   629→    85→```toml
   642→   630→    86→[traefik]
   643→   631→    87→enabled = true
   644→   632→    88→dashboard_port = 8080
   645→   633→    89→domain = "pan.localhost"
   646→   634→    90→```
   647→   635→    91→
   648→   636→    92→### 7. Minimal Install (--minimal flag)
   649→   637→    93→Skip Traefik entirely, use port-based routing:
   650→   638→    94→- `http://localhost:3001` (dashboard frontend)
   651→   639→    95→- `http://localhost:3002` (dashboard API)
   652→   640→    96→
   653→   641→    97→## What's In Scope
   654→   642→    98→
   655→   643→    99→1. Traefik docker-compose.yml and configuration
   656→   644→   100→2. mkcert certificate generation for wildcard domains
   657→   645→   101→3. Static Traefik config (traefik.yml)
   658→   646→   102→4. Dynamic config for Panopticon dashboard routing
   659→   647→   103→5. Update `pan install` to set up Traefik
   660→   648→   104→6. Update `pan up` and `pan down` to manage Traefik container
   661→   649→   105→7. DNS/hosts file instructions and helper scripts

   663→   651→   107→
   664→   652→   108→## What's Out of Scope
   665→   653→   109→
   666→   654→   110→1. Workspace-specific dynamic routing (that's for workspace create/start)
   667→   655→   111→2. Project-specific routing (e.g., `*.myn.localhost`)
   668→   656→   112→3. Windows native support (WSL2 only for now)

   854→- Simpler - one domain pattern for everyone

   561→    17→
   562→    18→**Rationale:**
   563→    19→- `.localhost` is a reserved TLD that resolves to 127.0.0.1 on most systems

   570→    26→### 1. Traefik Runs in Docker Only
   571→    27→- **Not** containerizing the dashboard itself

   573→    29→- Dashboard continues to run on ports 3001 (frontend) and 3002 (API)
   574→    30→
   575→    31→### 2. Directory Structure
   576→    32→```
   577→    33→~/.panopticon/
   578→    34→├── traefik/

   588→    44→```

   594→    50→Generates wildcard certs for:

Good question. Let me think through the distinction:

**Current Plan:**
- `pan.localhost` - for Panopticon **users** (accessing the dashboard they installed)

**Your Question:**
- Should **Panopticon developers** (working on the framework itself) have a different domain?

Here's my thinking:

**Option A: Single domain for both (`pan.localhost`)**
- Simpler - one domain pattern for everyone
- Developers just run `pan up` in their dev checkout
- No confusion about which URL to use

**Option B: Separate dev domain (`pan-dev.localhost`)**
- Clear separation between "using Panopticon" vs "developing Panopticon"
- Could run both simultaneously (production install + dev checkout)
- More cognitive overhead

**Option C: Use `panopticon.dev` for developers only**
- Requires hosts file entry (not auto-resolving like `.localhost`)
- `.dev` is a real TLD owned by Google, so there's collision risk
- But also clearly signals "this is development work"

My recommendation: **Option A (single domain)**

Reasoning:
1. Panopticon developers ARE users - they're just running from source instead of npm install
2. If someone needs to run both (rare), they can manually configure a different port
3. `.localhost` auto-resolves, reducing setup friction
4. The workspace pattern already handles project separation (`feature-pan-4.localhost` etc.)

Does that logic track? Or do you have a specific use case where you'd need both running simultaneously?

# Panopticon Traefik Reverse Proxy
# This file is managed by Panopticon - changes will be overwritten on update

services:
  traefik:
    image: traefik:v3.2
    container_name: panopticon-traefik
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - "443:443"
      - "8080:8080"  # Traefik dashboard
    volumes:
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock:ro
      - ./traefik.yml:/etc/traefik/traefik.yml:ro
      - ./dynamic:/etc/traefik/dynamic:ro
      - ./certs:/etc/traefik/certs:ro
    extra_hosts:
      - "host.docker.internal:host-gateway"
    labels:
      - "traefik.enable=true"
      - "traefik.http.routers.traefik-dashboard.rule=Host(`traefik.pan.localhost`)"
      - "traefik.http.routers.traefik-dashboard.entrypoints=websecure"
      - "traefik.http.routers.traefik-dashboard.tls=true"
      - "traefik.http.routers.traefik-dashboard.service=api@internal"

networks:
  default:
    name: panopticon-network
    external: false

tool_use_result.content:
# Panopticon Traefik Reverse Proxy
# This file is managed by Panopticon - changes will be overwritten on update

services:
  traefik:
    image: traefik:v3.2
    container_name: panopticon-traefik
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - "443:443"
      - "8080:8080"  # Traefik dashboard
    volumes:
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock:ro
      - ./traefik.yml:/etc/traefik/traefik.yml:ro
      - ./dynamic:/etc/traefik/dynamic:ro
      - ./certs:/etc/traefik/certs:ro
    extra_hosts:
      - "host.docker.internal:host-gateway"
    labels:
      - "traefik.enable=true"
      - "traefik.http.routers.traefik-dashboard.rule=Host(`traefik.pan.localhost`)"
      - "traefik.http.routers.traefik-dashboard.entrypoints=websecure"
      - "traefik.http.routers.traefik-dashboard.tls=true"
      - "traefik.http.routers.traefik-dashboard.service=api@internal"

networks:
  default:
    name: panopticon-network
    external: false

input.content:
# Panopticon Traefik Static Configuration
# This file is managed by Panopticon - changes will be overwritten on update

# API and Dashboard
api:
  dashboard: true
  insecure: false

# Entry Points
entryPoints:
  websecure:
    address: ":443"

# Providers
providers:
  docker:
    endpoint: "unix:///var/run/docker.sock"
    exposedByDefault: false
    network: panopticon-network
  file:
    directory: /etc/traefik/dynamic
    watch: true

# TLS Configuration
tls:
  stores:
    default:
      defaultCertificate:
        certFile: /etc/traefik/certs/localhost.pem
        keyFile: /etc/traefik/certs/localhost-key.pem

# Logging
log:
  level: INFO
  format: common

accessLog:
  filePath: ""
  format: common
  filters:
    statusCodes:
      - "400-599"

input.content:
# Panopticon Dashboard Routing
# Routes requests to the Panopticon dashboard running on the host

http:
  routers:
    # Main dashboard frontend
    panopticon-frontend:
      rule: "Host(`pan.localhost`)"
      entryPoints:
        - websecure
      service: panopticon-frontend
      tls: {}
      priority: 10

    # API routes (higher priority than frontend)
    panopticon-api:
      rule: "Host(`pan.localhost`) && PathPrefix(`/api`)"
      entryPoints:
        - websecure
      service: panopticon-api
      tls: {}
      priority: 20

  services:
    panopticon-frontend:
      loadBalancer:
        servers:
          - url: "http://host.docker.internal:3001"
        passHostHeader: true

    panopticon-api:
      loadBalancer:
        servers:
          - url: "http://host.docker.internal:3002"
        passHostHeader: true

content.text: Now I need to add a template for workspace-specific dynamic configs. This will be used when workspaces are created:

input.content:
# Workspace Routing Template
# This template is used to generate dynamic configs for workspaces
# Variables: {{WORKSPACE_NAME}}, {{PROJECT_NAME}}, {{FRONTEND_PORT}}, {{API_PORT}}

http:
  routers:
    # Workspace frontend
    {{WORKSPACE_NAME}}-frontend:
      rule: "Host(`{{WORKSPACE_NAME}}.{{PROJECT_NAME}}.localhost`)"
      entryPoints:
        - websecure
      service: {{WORKSPACE_NAME}}-frontend
      tls: {}

    # Workspace API (if API port is specified)
    {{WORKSPACE_NAME}}-api:
      rule: "Host(`api-{{WORKSPACE_NAME}}.{{PROJECT_NAME}}.localhost`)"
      entryPoints:
        - websecure
      service: {{WORKSPACE_NAME}}-api
      tls: {}

  services:
    {{WORKSPACE_NAME}}-frontend:
      loadBalancer:
        servers:
          - url: "http://host.docker.internal:{{FRONTEND_PORT}}"
        passHostHeader: true

    {{WORKSPACE_NAME}}-api:
      loadBalancer:
        servers:
          - url: "http://host.docker.internal:{{API_PORT}}"
        passHostHeader: true
